title: 108_hr2601
content: The "Public Domain Enhancement Act" may be cited as the short title. The findings section is included in the Act. The Congress finds that the copyright clause in the United States Constitution grants Congress the power to promote the progress of science and useful arts by securing exclusive rights to authors for limited times, providing an economic incentive for creating new works. The copyright term is limited to prevent permanent deprivation of the public from an artist's work. Both commercial and noncommercial creators benefit from a healthy public domain, with book publishers printing titles from the public domain for availability. The public domain is utilized for various purposes such as creating new productions, educational materials, and benefiting media sources like the World Wide Web. The public domain, including historical materials from sources like the Library of Congress on the World Wide Web, benefits from copyright protection laws that still apply to works published as early as 1923. However, a study shows that only 2 percent of works between 55 and 75 years old retain commercial value, indicating that many older works are no longer commercially available. Despite this, abandoned works under current law will not enter the public domain for many years. Abandoned works under current copyright law will not enter the public domain for many years, hindering entities from utilizing them. This contradicts the original intent of copyright laws and deprives the public of valuable historical resources. The Copyright Act aims to prevent the public from being deprived of works without commercial or copyright purpose. A mechanism is needed for abandoned American copyrights to enter the public domain. SEC. 3. MAINTENANCE FEE FOR PUBLISHED UNITED STATES WORKS. The definition of "United States work" in section 101 of title 17, United States Code, is amended for sections 306 and 411. Section 302 of title 17 is amended for works created on or after January 1, 1978, regarding the duration of copyright. Section 303(a) of title 17, United States Code, is amended for works created but not published or copyrighted before January 1, 1978. This includes changes to the language regarding copyright and exceptions, subject to section 306. Section 304 of title 17, United States Code, is amended for subsisting copyrights, subject to section 306. This includes changes to subparagraphs (B) and (C) in subsection (a). Section 304 of title 17, United States Code, is amended for subsisting copyrights, subject to section 306. This includes changes to subparagraphs (B) and (C) in subsection (a). In subsection (b), "Any" is struck. Section 304 of title 17, United States Code is amended by striking "Any" in subsection (b) and inserting "Subject to section 306, any". A new section 306 is added for maintenance fees for published United States works, with a fee of $1 due every 10 years after the date of first publication. The copyright in a work must have the maintenance fee paid to remain in force, or it will expire after a grace period of 6 months. Ancillary or promotional works connected to the main work are also covered. Maintenance fees are required every 10 years for published United States works. The maintenance fee for copyright must be paid every 10 years to keep the work protected. The fee must be accompanied by a prescribed form that aligns with registration requirements. Additional materials may be required by the Register of Copyrights. Maintenance fee for published United States works is required every 10 years to keep the copyright protected. The fee must be paid along with a prescribed form that meets registration requirements, and additional materials may be requested by the Register of Copyrights. Additionally, Section 708(a) of title 17, United States Code, is amended to include the maintenance fee under section 306. The Register of Copyrights must establish procedures within 12 months to ease the submission of forms and make the information easily accessible to the public under section 306(c) of title 17, United States Code.
